[[File:Status of Common Core Standards vector.svg|thumb|A map showing states in the U.S. which have either adopted, not adopted, partially adopted, or repealed the Common Core State Standards: {{legend|#0066cc|States that have adopted the Standards}} {{legend|#00cccc|States that have partially adopted the Standards}} {{legend|#f9ca68|States that adopted but later repealed the Standards}} {{legend|#bf8040|States that never adopted the Standards}}]] 46 states initially adopted the [[Common Core State Standards]], although implementation has not been uniform. At least 12 states have introduced legislation to repeal the standards outright,<ref>''Bloomberg'': [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-02-10/common-core-isn-t-a-government-conspiracy.html Common Core Isn’t a Government Conspiracy.] February 10, 2014.</ref> and Indiana has since withdrawn from the standards.
Among the territories of the United States, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the American Samoa Islands have adopted the standards while Puerto Rico has not adopted the standards. Arizona had also successfully repealed Common Core as of 2015; infographic to be updated later.
==Alabama== Alabama initially adopted the Standards, but the state rescinded adoption in November 2013. Governor [[Robert J. Bentley|Robert Bentley]] cited federal interventions as a reason for his opposition, saying he was opposed because of "federal control of our education system. And I'm opposed to the Common Core because of the potential for federal intrusion."<ref name="AL">AL.com: [http://blog.al.com/wire/2013/11/unlike_alabama_these_five_stat.html Unlike Alabama, these five states didn't adopt the Common Core]. November 12, 2013.</ref> The state's curriculum, now called the College and Career Ready Standards, is still aligned with the Common Core standards.<ref>AL.com: [http://blog.al.com/wire/2013/11/common_core.html Common Core: Alabama votes to distance itself from controversial standards.] November 16, 2013.</ref>
==Alaska== Alaska opted out of adopting the Standards. While debate persists in Alaska, the state has adopted its own new standards called the Alaska Content and Performance Standards that Education Commissioner Mike Hanley has described as "substantially similar" to the Common Core standards, and many local districts have chosen to adopt the standards even though the state has not.<ref>''Alaska Dispatch'': [http://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/20140108/skeptics-keep-pressure-against-alaska-common-core-education-standards Skeptics keep up pressure against Alaska Common Core education standards]. January 8, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://education.alaska.gov/standards/ |title=EED-Standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher=Alaska Department of Early Education and Development |access-date=2015-07-16 |quote=}}</ref> Parents have the right to opt their kids out of standardized testing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.tenthamendmentcenter.com/2016/10/now-in-effect-new-alaska-law-taking-first-step-against-common-core/|title=Now in Effect: New Alaska Law Taking First Step Against Common Core|date=2016-10-26|newspaper=Tenth Amendment Center Blog|access-date=2017-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Arizona== Arizona formally adopted the Standards. In 2014, Governor [[Jan Brewer]] signed an executive order that removes references to "Common Core" from the state's math and reading standards, although they are still aligned with the national standards.<ref name="FoxNameGame">Fox News: [http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/02/18/name-game-amid-opposition-states-change-title-common-core/ Name game: Amid opposition, states change title of Common Core]. February 14, 2014.</ref> The name of the standards have been changed to "Arizona's College and Career Ready Standards."<ref name="USNewsRepeal" /> In the legislature, the Senate Education Committee passed a bill that would withdraw Arizona from Common Core.<ref>''East Valley Tribune'': [http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/arizona/politics/article_6ee155b4-9a7b-11e3-a6f2-0019bb2963f4.html Senate Education Committee approves law to halt Common Core implementation.] February 20, 2014.</ref> As of October 26, 2015, the Arizona State Board of Education elected to repeal the Common Core standards in a 6-2 vote.
==Arkansas== Arkansas formally adopted the Standards in 2010. Multiple proposals during the 2014 fiscal year in the state legislature to delay implementation were not adopted.<ref>Associated Press: [http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/90eb775ac4ca47b2ab788c6bf0c13622/AR--XGR-Arkansas-Legislature-Common-Core Arkansas lawmakers vote against delaying Common Core education benchmarks] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140317123408/http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/90eb775ac4ca47b2ab788c6bf0c13622/AR--XGR-Arkansas-Legislature-Common-Core |date=2014-03-17 }}. February 19, 2014.</ref> Arkansas is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/arkansas |title=Arkansas |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-16 |quote=}}</ref>
==California== California formally adopted the Standards. Governor [[Jerry Brown]] allocated $1.25 billion in the state budget to assist with implementation, but also assured educators that Core-aligned tests will not be used as part of teacher evaluations through the 2015-2016 school year. The grant remains controversial with California teacher's unions because of concerns of the use and size of the grant.<ref name="EdWeekCC">''Education Week'': [http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2014/02/19/21commoncore.h33.html?tkn=QVYFQcC934kasAAD2IP5%2F%2FrinA7dkahqF0kX&cmp=clp-edweek Common-Core Tensions Cause Union Heartburn] February 18, 2014.</ref> California is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states">{{cite web |url=http://www.smarterbalanced.org/about/member-states/ |title=Member States |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-16 |quote=}}</ref>
==Colorado== Colorado formally adopted the Standards in 2010. Citizen concerns about Common Core, however, have resulted in a bill drafted by a parent group to delay implementation and appoint an independent panel to look at the standards, with State Senator Vicki Marble agreeing to carry it in the legislature.<ref>''The Denver Post'': [http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_25004965/backlash-against-common-core-education-standards-surfaces-colorado Backlash against Common Core education standards surfaces in Colorado]. January 27, 2014.</ref>
==Connecticut== Connecticut formally adopted the Standards, but Governor Dannel Malloy has called for a delay in teacher evaluations based on Common Core testing, citing the stress of changing systems and saying "it's important that we relieve the significant demands on teachers and administrators and systems."<ref name="USNewsRepeal">''U.S. News & World Report'': [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/01/31/more-states-seek-to-repeal-common-core More States Seek to Repeal Common Core]. January 31, 2014.</ref> In a public forum in [[Old Lyme]], State Representative Marilyn Giuliano called on the state to "hit the pause button" on implementation,<ref>''The Day'': [http://www.theday.com/article/20140130/NWS01/301309491/1017 Caution urged as state weighs Common Core standards]. January 30, 2014.</ref> saying she had introduced legislation to delay implementation until legislators had heard feedback.<ref name="USNewsRepeal" /> Connecticut is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Delaware== Delaware formally adopted the Standards as the ELA and math components of the Delaware Prioritized Standards. Implementation has been viewed as successful in the state.<ref>NPR: [https://www.npr.org/2013/09/22/225120320/in-push-for-common-standards-many-parents-left-uneducated In Push For 'Common' Standards, Many Parents Left Uneducated]. September 22, 2013.</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doe.k12.de.us/Page/1450 |title=The Delaware Prioritized Curriculum and Common Core State Standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Delaware Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-16 |quote=}}</ref> Delaware is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==District of Columbia== Washington, DC, has adopted the Standards. The District of Columbia's implementation is noteworthy for the speed and investment it made in the standards.<ref>''Education Week'': [http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2013/05/22/32common_ep.h32.html D.C. Bets Big on Common Core]. May 21, 2013.</ref> The District of Columbia is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/district-columbia |title=District of Columbia |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Florida== Florida initially adopted the Standards, but Gov. [[Rick Scott]] has directed the state education board to withdraw from the Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for College and Careers.<ref>''Florida Times-Union'': [http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2013-10-17/story/common-core-still-moving-ahead-florida#ixzz2mL66PT5a Common Core still moving ahead in Florida.] October 16, 2013</ref> Scott also changed the name of the standards in Florida to Next Generation Sunshine State Standards, saying "These are Florida standards...This is our state. We’re not going to have the federal government telling us how to do our education system."<ref name="FoxNameGame" />
In February 2014, the Department of Education approved 98 different changes to the Florida standards, scheduled to be implemented in the 2014-2015 school year.<ref>News 13: [http://www.mynews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/cfn/2014/2/18/state_board_of_educa.html Florida Common Core changes approved despite protest at Orlando meeting]. February 18, 2014.</ref>
==Georgia== Georgia formally adopted the Standards, but withdrew from the associated tests in July 2013.<ref>Bailey Pritchett, Heartland Foundation, http://news.heartland.org/newspaper-article/2013/07/22/common-core-testing-costs-increase-georgia-withdraws</ref> While implementation had been on track for the state, State Senator William Ligon filed legislation to withdraw from the Common Core entirely.<ref>''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'': [http://www.ajc.com/weblogs/get-schooled/2014/feb/04/too-late-stop-common-core-georgia/ Too late to stop Common Core in Georgia?]. February 4, 2014.</ref> On 19 February 2015, Georgia formally renamed its standards the Georgia Standards of Excellence, which incorporate some revisions relative to the Common Core standards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.georgiastandards.org/Georgia-Standards/Pages/default.aspx |title=Georgia Standards of Excellence |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Georgia Standards |publisher=Georgia Department of Education |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Hawaii== Hawaii formally adopted the Standards, with full classroom implementation beginning in the 2013-14 school year and aligned assessment beginning in 2014-15.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hawaiipublicschools.org/TeachingAndLearning/StudentLearning/CommonCoreStateStandards/Pages/FAQs.aspx |title=Common Core FAQs |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Hawaii State Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref> Hawaii is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Idaho== Idaho formally adopted the Standards as the ELA and math components of the Idaho Core Standards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sde.idaho.gov/site/common/ |title=Idaho Core Standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Idaho State Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref> Idaho is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]] and began testing in 2014.<ref name="sbac-states" /><ref>''Idaho State Journal'': [http://www.idahostatejournal.com/members/common-core-faces-april-test/article_4b279d9c-9957-11e3-b521-0019bb2963f4.html Common Core faces April test]. February 19, 2014.</ref>
==Illinois== Illinois formally adopted the Standards and rolled out implementation during the 2013-14 school year.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.isbe.state.il.us/common_core/default.htm |title=New Illinois learning standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Illinois State Board of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref> Illinois is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/illinois |title=Illinois |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Indiana== Indiana initially adopted the Standards, but implementation was paused by law in May 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.in.gov/apps/lsa/session/billwatch/billinfo?year=2013&request=getBill&docno=1427 |title=DIGEST OF HB 1427 |date=2013-04-26}}</ref> A bipartisan legislative panel failed to come to a consensus on continuing with the standards, and repeal legislation passed both the Indiana Senate and the State House Education Committee in February 2014,<ref>WLFI: [http://wlfi.com/2014/02/20/indiana-house-committee-votes-to-nix-common-core/ Indiana House committee votes to nix Common Core]. February 20, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.in.gov/legislative/bills/2013/PDF/Srollcal/0169.PDF.pdf |title=INDIANA STATE SENATE Roll Call Number: 169 |date=2013-02-21}}</ref> and the state formally withdrew from the Common Core in March 2014.<ref>WANE: [http://wane.com/news/indiana/pence-approves-withdrawal-from-common-core/ Indiana becomes first state to drop Common Core.] March 25, 2014.</ref> The state published its replacement, the Indiana Academic Standards, in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doe.in.gov/standards |title=Indiana Academic Standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Indiana Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Iowa== Iowa formally adopted the Standards as the ELA and math components of Iowa Core, the state's K-12 curriculum standards.<ref name="FoxNameGame" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://iowacore.gov/about-iowa-core |title=About Iowa Core |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=IowaCORE |publisher=Iowa Department of Education |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref> Common Core was adopted in Iowa in 2010, with full implementation slated for completion in the 2014-2015 school year.<ref>''The Gazette'': [http://thegazette.com/2014/02/13/a-quick-course-on-common-core-iowa-core/ A quick course on Common Core, Iowa Core]. February 13, 2014.</ref> Iowa is an affiliate member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Kansas== Kansas formally adopted the Standards in 2010,<ref>KAKE: [http://www.kake.com/home/headlines/House-Committee-hears-Common-Core-debate-246259971.html House Committee hears Common Core debate] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302064036/http://www.kake.com/home/headlines/House-Committee-hears-Common-Core-debate-246259971.html |date=2014-03-02 }}. February 19, 2014.</ref> but defunding legislation successfully passed the State Senate in July 2013, narrowly failing in the State House.<ref>Dion Lefler, ''Wichita Star,'' July 10, 2013 http://www.kansas.com/2013/07/10/2883171/demonstrators-protest-outside.html</ref> House Bill 2621 was introduced in the 2014 legislative session, and would declare the standards, as well as the Next Generation science standards the state adopted in 2013, "null and void" in the state.<ref>''The Wichita Eagle'': [http://www.kansas.com/2014/02/19/3298877/kansas-house-committee-to-hear.html Kansas House committee hears debate on Common Core standards]. February 19, 2014.</ref> However, as of 2015, the Common Core standards, with additions specified by the state Board of Education, remain part of the Kansas College and Career Ready Standards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://community.ksde.org/Default.aspx?tabid=5276 |title=Kansas College and Career Ready Standards for Mathematics |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Kansas State Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://community.ksde.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=tzz1aDOC0v8%3d&tabid=5559&mid=13575 |title=English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Kansas State Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
Kansas was formerly a member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]], but the Kansas State Board of Education withdrew from the consortium in 2013, instead planning to commission its assessment development in-state from an institute at Kansas University. Testing using this instrument will begin in spring 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cjonline.com/news/2013-12-10/kansas-opts-create-its-own-common-core-tests |title=Kansas opts to create its own Common Core tests |last1=Llopis-Jepsen |first1=Celia |last2= |first2= |date=2013-12-10 |website= |publisher=Topeka Capital-Journal |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Kentucky== Kentucky was the first state to adopt Common Core in 2010 as part of the Kentucky Core Academic Standards, with curriculum rolled out in the 2011-12 school year.<ref name="AtlanticCC">''The Atlantic'': [https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2013/10/what-kentucky-can-teach-the-rest-of-the-us-about-the-common-core/280453/ What Kentucky Can Teach the Rest of the U.S. About the Common Core]. October 15, 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://education.ky.gov/comm/UL/Pages/Kentucky-Core-Academic-Standards.aspx |title=Kentucky Core Academic Standards |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2015-03-13 |website=Kentucky Department of Education |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref> It was recently repealed in February 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/kentucky/articles/2017-03-15/charter-schools-bill-to-get-senate-vote-wednesday|title=GOP Eyes Charter Schools, Common Core Repeal|last=Beam|first=Adam|date=2017-03-15|website=USNews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317221923/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/kentucky/articles/2017-03-15/charter-schools-bill-to-get-senate-vote-wednesday|archive-date=2017-03-17|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
==Louisiana== Louisiana formally adopted the Standards, but delayed full Common Core implementation for two years in November 2013.<ref>''New Orleans Times-Picayune'': [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/11/louisiana_common_core_parcc_de.html Louisiana announces major changes to how students, schools held accountable under Common Core.] November 21, 2013.</ref> Debate is expected when the state legislature convenes in March 2014, but testing is still scheduled to be implemented for the 2014-2015 school year.<ref>''The Advocate'': [http://theadvocate.com/home/8410402-125/story.html Common Core critics plan public forum.] February 20, 2014.</ref> Governor [[Bobby Jindal]] has signaled an intention to end Common Core in the state, directing the Board of Education and the legislature to come up with an alternative that includes "Louisiana standards and a Louisiana test."<ref>''The Times-Picayune'': [http://www.nola.com/education/index.ssf/2014/06/bobby_jindals_common_core_anno.html Gov. Bobby Jindal's attempt to scuttle Common Core leaves Louisiana education system in confusion.] June 18, 2014.</ref> [[Bobby Jindal]] curricular changes include rejection of the Common Core education standards for teaching English and math. In a response, several charter schools led by teachers and parents filed a lawsuit against the governor.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaminski|first1=Jonathan|title=Lawsuit challenges Louisiana governor's plan to ditch Common Core|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/07/23/us-usa-louisiana-commoncore-idUSKBN0FS1T720140723|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref>
Louisiana is an affiliate member of [[PARCC]] and its state assessment "includes items developed through the PARCC process".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/louisiana |title=Louisiana |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Maine== Maine formally adopted the Standards. The [[Maine Equal Rights Center]] has launched a petition drive to add a question on the 2014 ballot that would remove Maine from Common Core,<ref>''Bangor Daily News'': [https://bangordailynews.com/2013/08/21/politics/petition-drive-begins-to-pull-maine-out-of-45-state-education-collaborative/ Petition drive begins to pull Maine out of 45-state Common Core education collaborative]. August 21, 2013.</ref> but Governor [[Paul LePage]] has shown support for the standards.<ref>''Bangor Daily News'': [https://bangordailynews.com/2013/12/06/politics/former-maine-gov-mckernan-defends-embattled-common-core-standards-at-education-conference/ Former Gov. McKernan defends embattled Common Core standards at education conference]. December 6, 2013.</ref> Maine recently withdrew from [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Maryland== Maryland formally adopted the Standards, although there has been significant resistance to the implementation in the state from educators, lawmakers, and citizens, including a planned push by State Republican legislators to withdraw from the consortium.<ref>''Washington Post'': [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/answer-sheet/wp/2013/11/25/common-core-resistance-growing-in-maryland/ Common Core resistance growing in Maryland.] November 25, 2013.</ref> Maryland is one of five states that has received permission from the federal government, under [[No Child Left Behind]], to not test students under both Common Core and the state-level tests.<ref>''Washington Post'': [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/maryland-students-avoid-double-testing/2014/02/14/54b40b72-95ae-11e3-9616-d367fa6ea99b_story.html Maryland students avoid ‘double-testing’.] February 14, 2014.</ref>
Legislation has also been filed in the state senate to delay teacher evaluation based on Common Core tests until the 2016-2017. This legislation is supported by the Maryland Superintendent of Schools Lillian Lowery. Another Senate bill has been filed that would leave teacher performance evaluations in the hands of local school boards.<ref>''Maryland Reporter'': [http://marylandreporter.com/2014/02/19/md-schools-superintendent-supports-delay-of-teacher-evaluations-based-on-common-core-tests/ Md. schools superintendent supports delay of teacher evaluations based on Common Core tests.] February 19, 2014.</ref>
Maryland is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/maryland |title=Maryland |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Massachusetts== Massachusetts formally adopted the Standards, but delayed transition to the Common Core for two years in November 2013.<ref>''Education Week'': [http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/state_edwatch/2013/11/two-year_transition_to_common-core_tests_approved_in_massachusetts.html Two-Year Transition to Common-Core Tests Approved in Massachusetts.] November 19, 2013.</ref> common core was rescinded in 2017
==Michigan== Michigan formally adopted the Standards, although implementation was paused for a time and was later approved to continue without the Smarter Balanced testing.<ref>CBS Detroit: [http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2013/11/02/michigan-gives-final-ok-to-common-core-standards/ http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2013/11/02/michigan-gives-final-ok-to-common-core-standards/ Michigan Gives Final OK To Common Core Standards]. November 2, 2013</ref> Michigan is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Minnesota== Minnesota partially adopted the Standards. The state chose to adopt the English standards only, rejecting the math standards in favor of their own.<ref>MPR: [http://www.mprnews.org/story/2013/06/07/education/common-core-standards Minn. moves ahead with some Common Core education standards.] June 7, 2013.</ref>
==Mississippi== Mississippi formally adopted the Standards.
Mississippi is an affiliate member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/mississippi |title=Mississippi |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Missouri== Missouri formally adopted the Standards. Opposition to Common Core has been labeled as paranoia by some state legislators, causing one State Representative on the education panel to add an $8 appropriation for "two rolls of high density aluminum to create headgear designed to deflect drone and/or black helicopter mind reading and control technology."<ref>''The Kansas City Star'': [http://www.kansascity.com/2014/02/19/4834803/in-a-jab-at-common-core-opponents.html In a jab at Common Core opponents, Missouri House panel recommends $8 for tin foil hats]. February 19, 2014.</ref> Missouri is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Montana== Montana formally adopted the Standards. Multiple Montana education award winners wrote an opinion piece supporting Common Core,<ref>''Missoulian'': [http://missoulian.com/news/opinion/columnists/montana-presidential-award-winning-teachers-support-common-core/article_3926a370-89b9-11e3-a62d-0019bb2963f4.html Montana Presidential Award-winning teachers support Common Core]. January 30, 2014.</ref> and, among educators and legislators, adoption has gone smoothly, but there has been pushback by some who voice concern about state sovereignty and that implementation violates the Montana State Constitution.<ref>''Billings Gazette'': [http://billingsgazette.com/news/local/education/common-core-sees-delayed-pushback-leaving-educators-to-scratch-their/article_48d23eab-994f-5009-a4e0-ce20578d0b83.html Common Core sees delayed pushback, leaving educators to scratch their heads]. December 15, 2013.</ref> Montana is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Nebraska== Nebraska did not adopt the Standards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theindependent.com/news/local/nebraska-one-of-few-states-not-adopting-standards/article_e433baec-57aa-11e2-ad93-001a4bcf887a.html|work=The Grand Island Independent|title=Nebraska one of few states not adopting standards|date=2013-01-05}}</ref> Reasons cited for not adopting included skepticism about the math standards and the lack of formalized standards being available at the time of adoption.<ref name="AL" />
==Nevada== Nevada formally adopted the Standards in 2012. There has been no significant opposition to the implementation, but the Department of Education launched a messaging campaign in February 2014 to quell a growing backlash in Northern Nevada.<ref>RGJ.com: [http://www.rgj.com/article/20140217/NEWS02/302170007/Nevada-education-Report-card-Common-Core-messaging-picks-up Nevada education Report card: Common Core messaging picks up]. February 17, 2014.</ref> Nevada is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==New Hampshire== New Hampshire formally adopted the Standards. A bill to withdraw from the standards is currently in the New Hampshire House of Representatives, but the state is still on track to begin testing in Spring 2015.<ref>New Hampshire Public Radio: [http://nhpr.org/post/bill-pull-nh-out-common-core-goes-house-committee Bill To Pull N.H. Out Of Common Core Goes Before House Committee.] February 20, 2014.</ref> New Hampshire is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==New Jersey== New Jersey formally adopted the Standards. New Jersey's Board of Education has repeatedly passed resolutions reaffirming their commitment to the standards.<ref>''The Star-Ledger'': [http://www.nj.com/education/2014/02/nj_state_board_of_education_backs_common_core_standards_again.html NJ State Board of Education backs Common Core standards, again]. February 13, 2014.</ref> Governor Chris Christie has vowed to pull the state out of common core.<ref>[http://dailysignal.com/2015/05/28/christie-vows-to-scrap-common-core-in-new-jersey/]</ref>
New Jersey is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/new-jersey |title=New Jersey |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==New Mexico== New Mexico formally adopted the Standards. New Mexico is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/new-mexico |title=New Mexico |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==New York== New York formally adopted the Standards. The State Board of Regents delayed implementation for five extra years in February 2014 to give schools more time to implement, as well as offering teachers two years amnesty from being evaluated on the standards. This delay means that the standards will not be a requirement for high school students until 2022.<ref>''New York Daily News'': [http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/education/ny-teachers-years-common-core-article-1.1609007 New York teachers get five years to fully enact Common Core]. February 10, 2014.</ref> Issues have also prompted the state's leading teacher union, [[New York State Teachers United]], to withdraw their support of the standards "as implemented," also calling for the resignation of State Education Commissioner John King and a three-year moratorium on testing. Other implementation actions have occurred, however, with Governor Andrew Cuomo convening an oversight panel.<ref name="EdWeekCC" />
New York is a governing member of [[PARCC]], but is not yet using their assessments statewide; in 2015 they are piloting the test in 25 schools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/parcc-states |title=PARCC States |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==North Carolina== North Carolina formally adopted the Standards. The state was one of the first to adopt the standards, but hearings were held in 2014 to discuss the future of the standards in the state, with Lieutenant Governor Dan Forest calling for a commission to complete a detailed review of the standards.<ref>''News Observer'': [http://www.newsobserver.com/2014/02/20/3640093/teachers-and-school-administrators.html Teachers and school administrators talk Common Core with legislators]. February 20, 2014.</ref> The North Carolina general assembly will consider a bill in May 2014 that would result in North Carolina moving away from the standards while creating a new set of educational standards to replace it.<ref>WRAL: [http://www.wral.com/lawmakers-propose-dumping-common-core-standards-in-nc/13591055/ Lawmakers propose dumping Common Core standards in NC.] April 24, 2014.</ref> North Carolina is an affiliate member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==North Dakota== North Dakota formally adopted the Standards. A Bill proposed in the state legislature on 2/12/2015 to eliminate common core in the state schools was defeated 46-48. North Dakota is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Ohio== Ohio formally adopted the Standards. In 2013, legislation was filed by Ohio Republicans to bar adoption of the standards.<ref>''Lancaster Eagle-Gazette'': [http://www.lancastereaglegazette.com/article/20131128/NEWS01/311280018/Ohio-Republicans-target-Common-Core Ohio Republicans target Common Core.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202193103/http://www.lancastereaglegazette.com/article/20131128/NEWS01/311280018/Ohio-Republicans-target-Common-Core |date=2013-12-02 }} November 29, 2013</ref> Another bill was introduced in January 2014 to end testing of students.<ref>''Marion Star'': [http://www.marionstar.com/article/20140129/NEWS01/301290004/Bill-targets-Common-Core-based-tests Bill targets Common Core-based tests] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140320135617/http://www.marionstar.com/article/20140129/NEWS01/301290004/Bill-targets-Common-Core-based-tests |date=2014-03-20 }}. January 30, 2014.</ref> Ohio recently withdrew from [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/ohio |title=Ohio |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==Oklahoma== Oklahoma formally adopted the Standards, but tentatively withdrew from the associated tests in July 2013.<ref>Benjamin Wood, "Education Week" http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/DigitalEducation/2013/07/tech_challenges_lead_oklahoma_.html</ref> Multiple bills had been introduced in the Oklahoma legislature to repeal the standards,<ref>KFOR: [http://kfor.com/2014/02/05/seven-bills-introduced-to-repeal-common-core-school-standards-in-oklahoma/ Seven bills introduced to repeal “Common Core” school standards in Oklahoma]. February 5, 2014.</ref><ref>' 'Daily Oklahoman' ': [http://newsok.com/oklahoma-senate-committee-votes-to-abolish-common-core-academic-standards/article/3946524 Oklahoma Senate committee votes to abolish Common Core academic standards.] March 24, 2014</ref> and the standards were officially repealed in June 2014.<ref>Politico: [http://www.politico.com/story/2014/06/common-core-repeal-oklahoma-mary-fallin-107499.html Mary Fallin signs bill repealing the Common Core.] June 5, 2014.</ref>
==Oregon== Oregon State Board of Education formally adopted the Standards on October 28, 2010, one of the first states to do so.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ode.state.or.us/news/announcements/announcement.aspx?ID=6156|title=Oregon State Board of Education Adopts Common Core Standards and Higher Interim Math Achievement Standards - Oregon Department of Education|date=October 28, 2010|website=www.ode.state.or.us|access-date=January 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/education/index.ssf/2014/11/what_is_common_core_a_guide_to.html|title=What is the Common Core? A guide to Oregon's new education standards|last=Hammond|first=Betsy|date=November 13, 2014|newspaper=OregonLive.com|access-date=January 1, 2017|via=}}</ref> Oregon is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Pennsylvania== Pennsylvania formally adopted the Standards, but Governor [[Tom Corbett]] paused implementation in May 2013 after finding a split among lawmaker opinion,<ref>''The Patriot-News'': [http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2013/05/corbett_orders_delay_in_common.html Corbett orders delay in Common Core academic standards' implementation.] May 20, 2013.</ref> and the state has announced they are withdrawing from associated tests.<ref>''Education Week'': [http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2014/01/29/19assessment_ep.h33.html Some Waiver States Feel Squeeze on Common-Core Tests.] January 28, 2014.</ref>
==Rhode Island== Rhode Island formally adopted the Standards, but, as of February 2014, calls for delays or repeal have increased, with State Representative Gregg Amore introducing legislation that would delay implementation.<ref>''Providence Journal'': [http://www.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/content/20140201-common-core-standards-for-education-draw-criticism-in-some-r.i.-communities.ece Common Core standards for education draw criticism in some R.I. communities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407074101/http://www.providencejournal.com/breaking-news/content/20140201-common-core-standards-for-education-draw-criticism-in-some-r.i.-communities.ece |date=2014-04-07 }}. February 1, 2014.</ref> Rhode Island is a governing member of [[PARCC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://parcconline.org/rhode-island |title=Rhode Island |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Partnership for Assessment of Readiness for Colleges and Careers |publisher= |access-date=2015-07-17 |quote=}}</ref>
==South Carolina== South Carolina formally adopted the Standards, although the standards have been controversial. Governor [[Nikki Haley]] criticized the standards, saying "We don’t ever want to educate South Carolina children like they educate California children."<ref name="FoxNameGame" /> A bill to repeal the standards beginning in the 2015-2016 school year was officially signed by Governor Haley in June 2014 after deliberation in the state legislature.<ref>''Education Week'': [S.C. Governor Signs Bill Requiring State to Replace Common Core http://blogs.edweek.org/edweek/state_edwatch/2014/06/south_carolina_gov_haley_signs_bill_to.html?cmp=SOC-SHR-TW.] June 4, 2014.</ref>
==South Dakota== South Dakota formally adopted the Standards. Multiple bills addressing Common Core are in the State Senate, but a bill that would have replaced Common Core with a different state standard was defeated in committee.<ref>''Argus Leader'': [https://archive.is/20140317123441/http://www.argusleader.com/article/20140218/UPDATES/302180038/Common-Core-replacement-South-Dakota-killed-committee Common Core replacement for South Dakota killed in committee.] February 18, 2014.</ref> South Dakota is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Tennessee== Tennessee formally adopted the Standards. According to polling done by the Tennessee Consortium on Research, Evaluation and Development, teachers in Tennessee have a positive outlook on the standards and implementation.<ref>Vanderbilt University: [http://news.vanderbilt.edu/2014/02/common-core-survey/ Tennessee teachers positive about Common Core, survey says.] February 4, 2014.</ref> The Bradley County Commission, however, voted to back bills in the Tennessee House and Senate that would "discontinue the use of the Common Core state standards."<ref>''Cleveland Daily Banner'': [https://archive.is/20140317123444/http://www.clevelandbanner.com/view/full_story/24610297/article-County-vote-opposes-Common-Core?instance=homefirstleft County vote opposes Common Core]. February 19, 2014.</ref> Multiple proposals have been filed to scale back, delay, or outright repeal the standards in Tennessee.<ref>Fox News: [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/02/07/tennessee-proposal-would-repeal-common-core-standards/ Tennessee proposal would repeal Common Core standards.] February 7, 2014.</ref><ref>''Murfreesboro Post'': [http://www.murfreesboropost.com/legislators-seek-changes-in-teacher-evaluations-common-core-curriculum-cms-38402 Legislators seek changes in teacher evaluations, Common Core curriculum]. February 20, 2014.</ref> Tennessee passed a law to phase out common core in 2016<ref>https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/education/2016/04/15/tennessee-phases-out-common-core/83085942/</ref>. The new standard, The Tennessee Academic Standards, were implemented in English and Math for the 2017/2018 school year.<ref>https://www.chalkbeat.org/posts/tn/2017/06/26/common-core-is-out-tennessee-academic-standards-are-in-heres-how-teachers-are-prepping-for-the-change/</ref>
==Texas== Texas did not adopt the Standards, and is not a member of the consortium. Governor [[Rick Perry]] opposed adoption in 2010, citing issues of states rights, federal intrusion in education, implementation costs, and "the adoption of unproven, cost-prohibitive national standards and tests."<ref name="AL" />
==Utah== Utah formally adopted the Standards, but withdrew from the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium in August 2012.<ref>''Salt Lake Tribune'': [http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/news/54627081-78/utah-state-standards-common.html.csp?page=1 Utah drops out of consortium developing Common Core tests.] August 1, 2012.</ref>
==Vermont== Vermont formally adopted the Standards. Vermont is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Virginia== Virginia did not adopt the Standards, and is not a member of the consortium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/344897/why-there-s-backlash-against-common-core-lindsey-m-burke|work=National Review Online|title= Why There’s a Backlash against Common Core|date=2013-04-08}}</ref> While the Virginia Board of Education opposed adoption, stating that they were "committed to the Virginia Standards of Learning (SOL) program and opposed to adoption of the newly developed Common Core State Standards as a prerequisite for participation in federal competitive grant and entitlement programs," a state evaluation found that the Standards of Learning were "generally aligned" with Common Core.<ref name="AL" />
==Washington== Washington formally adopted the Standards. Washington is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==West Virginia== West Virginia formally adopted the Standards. West Virginia renamed the standards "West Virginia's Next Generation Content Standards," and two bills have been filed in the state legislature. One bill, House Bill 4383, would delay implementation until 2016. The other, House Bill 4390, would withdraw West Virginia from Common Core completely.<ref>''State Journal'': [http://www.statejournal.com/story/24663278/house-members-take-a-step-back-from-common-core House members take a step back from Common Core]. February 7, 2014.</ref> West Virginia is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Wisconsin== Wisconsin formally adopted the Standards. A bill was fast-tracked in the legislature that would have repealed the standards in Wisconsin, but it was pulled from the floor in February 2014. It is believed that the bill will be reconsidered in March 2014.<ref>''The Capital Times'': [http://host.madison.com/ct/news/local/writers/jessica_vanegeren/bill-to-eliminate-common-core-in-wisconsin-abruptly-pulled-from/article_e48e83fc-9a55-11e3-ac72-0019bb2963f4.html Bill to eliminate Common Core in Wisconsin abruptly pulled from committee vote]. February 20, 2014.</ref> Governor [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]] supports the bill,<ref>''Green Bay Press Gazette'': [http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/viewart/20140219/GPG0101/302190235/Walker-backs-bill-undo-Common-Core-academic-standards Walker backs bill to undo Common Core academic standards]. February 19, 2014.</ref> while the Wisconsin Schools Superintendent Tony Evers has written to the legislature in opposition.<ref>''US News and World Report'': [https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/02/20/wisconsin-schools-chief-begs-public-to-stop-anti-common-core-vote Wisconsin Schools Chief Begs Public to Stop Anti-Common Core Vote]. February 20, 2014.</ref> Wisconsin is a governing member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />
==Wyoming== Wyoming formally adopted the Standards. A bill in the State House of Representatives would convene a panel of parents and educators to consider the future of Common Core in the state, as well as prohibits the state from entering into the Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium.<ref>''Wyoming Star-Tribune'': [http://trib.com/news/local/education/wyoming-house-to-consider-anti-common-core-bill/article_6070b633-418b-5979-bf3d-7c17a25c474c.html Wyoming House to consider anti-Common Core bill] February 19, 2014.</ref> Wyoming is an affiliate member of [[Smarter Balanced Assessment Consortium|SBAC]].<ref name="sbac-states" />

{{Infobox historical era | name = European Restoration | start = 1815 | end = 1849 | image = Europe 1815 map en.png | caption = The national boundaries within Europe as set by the [[Congress of Vienna]], 1815. | before = [[Napoleonic era]] | including = * [[Regency era]] * [[Bourbon Restoration]] * [[Revolutions of 1830]] * [[Revolutions of 1848]] | after = [[Romanticism|Romantic era]] | leaders = {{hlist|[[Klemens von Metternich]]|[[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord|Charles de Talleyrand]]|[[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis I of Austria]]|[[Ferdinand I of Austria]]|[[Louis XVIII of France]]|[[Charles X of France]]|[[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool|The Earl of Liverpool]]|[[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|The Duke of Wellington]]|[[Alexander I of Russia]]|[[Nicholas I of Russia]]}} }} {{about|the 19th-century diplomatic term| the jazz album| European Concert}} The '''Concert of Europe''', also known as the '''Congress System''' or the '''Vienna System''' after the [[Congress of Vienna]], was a system of [[dispute resolution]] adopted by the [[Great power|major powers]] of Europe to avoid future conflicts escalating into war, and to solidify and maintain their power in their respective controlled regions. The more conservative members of the Concert of Europe, who were also members of the [[#Holy Alliance|Holy Alliance]], used this system to oppose revolutionary movements, weaken the forces of nationalism, and uphold the [[Balance of power (international relations)|balance of power]]. Historians date its operation from the end of the [[Napoleonic Wars]] (1815) to the early 1820s, although some see it playing a role until the [[Crimean War]] (1853–1856).{{cite journal|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/world-politics/article/div-classtitlethe-concert-of-europe-a-fresh-look-at-an-international-systemdiv/6E95577CB092748E820521BC01F1564A|title=The Concert of Europe: A Fresh Look at an International System|first=Richard B.|last=Elrod|publisher=|journal=World Politics|volume=28|issue=2|pages=159–174|accessdate=16 June 2017|via=Cambridge Core|doi=10.2307/2009888}} == Overview == The Concert of Europe was founded by the powers of [[Austrian Empire|Austria]], [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]], [[Russian Empire|Russia]] and the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]], which were the members of the [[Quadruple Alliance (1815)|Quadruple Alliance]] that defeated [[Napoleon]] and his [[First French Empire]]. In time, [[France]] was established as a fifth member of the Concert, following the [[Bourbon Restoration|restoration of the Bourbon monarchy]]. At first, the leading personalities of the system were British foreign secretary [[Robert Stewart, Viscount Castlereagh|Lord Castlereagh]], Austrian Chancellor [[Klemens von Metternich]] and Tsar [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] of Russia. [[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord]] of France was largely responsible for quickly returning that country to its place alongside the other major powers in international diplomacy. [[File:Metternich (c. 1835-40).jpg|thumb|200px|[[Klemens von Metternich|Prince Metternich]], Austrian Chancellor and an influential leader in the Concert of Europe.]] The age of the Concert is sometimes known as the '''Age of Metternich''', due to the influence of the Austrian chancellor's [[conservatism]] and the dominance of Austria within the [[German Confederation]], or as the '''European Restoration''', because of the [[reactionary]] efforts of the Congress of Vienna to restore Europe to its state before the [[French Revolution]]. It is known in [[German language|German]] as the '''''Pentarchie''''' (pentarchy) and in [[Russian language|Russian]] as the '''Vienna System''' (Венская система, ''Venskaya sistema''). The Concert of Europe had no written rules or permanent institutions, but at times of crisis any of the member countries could propose a conference.{{cite book|last=Stevenson|first=David|title=1914 – 1918: The History of the First World War|year=2004|publisher=Penguin Books|isbn=978-0-14-026817-1|pages=4 |ref=harv}} Meetings of the [[Great Powers]] during this period included [[Congress of Aix-la-Chapelle (1818)|Aix-la-Chapelle]] (1818), [[Carlsbad Decrees|Carlsbad]] (1819), [[Congress of Troppau|Troppau]] (1820), [[Congress of Laibach|Laibach]] (1821), and [[Congress of Verona|Verona]] (1822). The Concert's effectiveness came to an end because of many factors such as the British distrust of Russia.{{cite book|author=Guy Arnold|title=Historical Dictionary of the Crimean War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_UreS--MoD0C&pg=PA65|year=2002|page=65}} == Origins == The idea of a European federation had been already raised by figures such as [[Gottfried Leibniz]]{{cite book |last=Loemker |first=Leroy |year=1969 |origyear=1956 |title=Leibniz: Philosophical Papers and Letters |publisher=Reidel |page=58, fn 9}} and [[William Grenville, 1st Baron Grenville|Lord Grenville]].{{cite journal |first=John M. |last=Sherwig |title=Lord Grenville's Plan for a Concert of Europe, 1797–99. |journal=The Journal of Modern History |volume=34 |number=3 |date=September 1962 |pages=284–293 |doi=10.1086/239117}} The Concert of Europe, as developed by Metternich, drew upon their ideas and the notion of a [[balance of power in international relations]], so that the ambitions of each [[Great Power]] would be restrained by the others:
The Concert of Europe, as it began to be called at the time, had ... a reality in international law, which derived from the [[Final Act of the Congress of Vienna|final Act of the Vienna Congress]], which stipulated that the boundaries established in 1815 could not be altered without the consent of its eight signatories.{{cite journal |first=Georges-Henri |last=Soutou |title=Was There a European Order in the Twentieth Century? From the Concert of Europe to the End of the Cold War |journal=Contemporary European History |volume=9 |number=3 |series=Theme Issue: Reflections on the Twentieth Century |date=November 2000 |pages=330 |ref=harv}}
=== French Revolution === From the outbreak of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]] in 1792 to the exile of [[Napoleon]] to [[Saint Helena]] in 1815, Europe had been almost constantly at war. During this time, the military conquests of [[France]] had resulted in the spread of [[liberalism]] throughout much of the continent, resulting in many states adopting the [[Napoleonic code]]. Largely as a reaction to the radicalism of the [[French Revolution]],{{sfn|Soutou|2000|p=329}} most victorious powers of the [[Napoleonic Wars]] resolved to suppress liberalism and [[nationalism]], and revert largely to the ''[[status quo]]'' of Europe prior to 1789.{{sfn|Soutou|2000|p=330}} === Holy Alliance === The [[Kingdom of Prussia]], and the [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] and [[Russian Empire|Russian]] empires, formed the [[Holy Alliance]] (26 September 1815) with the expressed intent of preserving [[Christian]] social values and traditional [[monarchism]].{{Cite CE1913|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07398a.htm |title=Spahn, M. (1910). Holy Alliance |date=1 June 1910 |accessdate=2011-05-21}} Every member of the anti-Napoleonic coalition promptly joined the Alliance, except for the United Kingdom, a [[constitutional monarchy]] with a more [[liberalism|liberal]] political philosophy. The great powers were now in a system of meeting wherever a problem arose. Britain and France did not send their representatives because they opposed the idea of intervention. === Quadruple Alliance === Britain did however ratify the [[Quadruple Alliance (1815)|Quadruple Alliance]], signed on the same day as the [[Treaty of Paris (1815)|Second Peace Treaty of Paris]] (20 November 1815), which became the [[Quintuple Alliance]] when France joined in 1818. It was also signed by the same three powers that had signed the Holy Alliance on 26 September 1815.{{cite book |last=Chapman |first=Tim |year=2006 |title=The Congress of Vienna 1814–1815 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781134680504 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Wn0G5na-1j0C&lpg=PA60&pg=PA60#v=onepage&q&f=false 60] |ref=harv}} === Differences between the Holy Alliance and the Quadruple Alliance === There has been much debate between historians as to which treaty was more influential in the development of international relations in Europe in the two decades following the end of the Napoleonic Wars. In the opinion of historian Tim Chapman the differences are somewhat academic, as the powers were not bound by the terms of the treaties and many of them intentionally broke the terms if it suited them.{{sfn|Chapman|2006|p=60}} The Holy Alliance was the brainchild of Tsar Alexander I. It gained a lot of support because most European monarchs did not wish to offend the Tsar by refusing to sign it, and as it bound monarchs personally rather than their governments, it was easy to ignore once signed. Only three notable princes did not sign: [[Pope Pius VII]] (it was not Catholic enough), [[Mahmud II|Sultan Mahmud II of the Ottoman Empire]], and [[George IV of the United Kingdom|the British Prince Regent]] because his government did not wish to pledge itself to the policing of continental Europe. In the opinion of Lord Castlereagh, the British foreign secretary at the time of its inception, the Holy Alliance was "a piece of sublime mysticism and nonsense".{{sfn|Chapman|2006|p=60}} Although it did not fit comfortably within the complex, sophisticated and cynical web of power politics that epitomised diplomacy of the post-Napoleonic era, its influence was more long lasting than its contemporary critics expected and was revived in the 1820s as a tool of repression when the terms of the Quintuple Alliance were not seen to fit the purposes of some of the Great Powers of Europe.{{sfn|Chapman|2006|p=61}} The Quadruple Alliance, by contrast, was a standard treaty, and the four Great Powers did not invite any of their allies to sign it. The primary objective was to bind the signatories to support the terms of the Second Treaty of Paris for 20 years. It included a provision for the High Contracting Parties to "renew their meeting at fixed periods...for the purpose of consulting on their common interests" which were the "prosperity of the Nations, and the maintenance of peace in Europe".{{sfn|Chapman|2006|p=62}} A problem with the wording of [[s:Quadruple Alliance#ART.VI|Article VI]] of the treaty is that it did not specify what these "fixed periods" were to be and there were no provisions in the treaty for a permanent commission to arrange and organise the conferences. This meant that the first conference in 1818 dealt with remaining issues of the French wars, but after that instead of meeting at "fixed periods" the meetings were arranged on an ad hoc basis, to address specific threats, such as those posed by [[revolution]]s, for which the treaty was not drafted.{{sfn|Chapman|2006|pp=61–62}} == Congresses == *The [[Congress of Aix-la-Chapelle (1818)]] resolved the issues of Allied occupation of France and restored that country to equal status with Britain, Prussia, Austria and Russia. *The [[Congress of Troppau|Congress of Troppau (1820)]] decreed that in the event of revolution a country could be expelled from the European Alliance, and armed intervention could be used to "bring back the guilty state into the bosom of the Great Alliance". *The [[Congress of Laibach|Congress of Laibach (1821)]] *In 1822, the [[Congress of Verona]] met to decide whether France could intervene on the side of the Spanish royalists in the ''[[Trienio Liberal]]''. After receiving permission, [[Louis XVIII]] dispatched five army corps to restore [[Ferdinand VII of Spain]]. == Collapse by 1823 == The territorial boundaries laid down at the Congress of Vienna were maintained; even more important, there was an acceptance of the theme of balance with no major aggression.Gordon Craig, "The System of Alliances and the Balance of Power." in J.P.T. Bury, ed., ''The New Cambridge Modern History, Vol. 10: The Zenith of European Power, 1830–70'' (1960) p 266. Otherwise, the Congress system, says historian Roy Bridge, "failed" by 1823.Roy Bridge, "Allied Diplomacy in Peacetime: The Failure of the Congress 'System,' 1815–23" in Alan Sked, ed., ''Europe's Balance of Power, 1815–1848'' (1979), pp 34–53 In 1818, the British decided [[Splendid Isolation|not to become involved in continental issues that did not directly affect them]]. They rejected the plan of Alexander I to suppress future revolutions. The Concert system fell apart as the common goals of the Great Powers were replaced by growing political and economic rivalries.C.W. Crawley, "International Relations, 1815–1830" in C.W. Crawley, ed., ''The New Cambridge Modern History: Volume 9, War and Peace in an Age of Upheaval, 1793–1830. Vol. 9'' (1965) pp 669–71, 676–77, 683–86. Artz says the [[Congress of Verona]] in 1822 "marked the end."Frederick B. Artz, ''Reaction & Revolution: 1814–1832'' (1934) p 170. There was no Congress called to restore the old system during the great [[Revolutions of 1848|revolutionary upheavals of 1848]] with their demands for revision of the Congress of Vienna's frontiers along national lines.Paul W. Schroeder, ''The Transformation of European Politics: 1763–1848'' (1996) p 800. Historian Paul Hayes says of British foreign minister [[George Canning]]: {{quote|His most important achievement was the destruction of the system of the neo-Holy Alliance which, if unchallenged, must have dominated Europe. Canning realized it was not enough for Britain to boycott conferences and congresses; it was essential to persuade the Powers that their interests could not be advanced by a system of intervention based upon principles of legitimacy, anti-nationalism and hostility to revolution. Paul Hayes, ''Modern British Foreign Policy: The 19th Century 1814–80'' (A&C Black, 1975) p 89}} ==See also== *[[European balance of power]] * [[International relations (1814–1919)]] *[[Balance of power in international relations]] *[[Great power]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Bridge, Roy, "Allied Diplomacy in Peacetime: The Failure of the Congress 'System,' 1815–23" in Alan Sked, ed., ''Europe's Balance of Power, 1815–1848'' (1979), pp 34–53. *{{cite book|last=Ghervas|first=Stella|title=Réinventer la tradition. Alexandre Stourdza et l'Europe de la Sainte-Alliance|publisher=Honoré Champion|year=2008|location=Paris|isbn=978-2-7453-1669-1}} *{{cite book|last=Jarrett|first=Mark|title=The Congress of Vienna and its Legacy: War and Great Power Diplomacy after Napoleon|publisher=I. B. Tauris & Company, Ltd.|year=2013|location=London|isbn=978-1780761169}} ==External links== *[[Encyc: Concert of Europe]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Concert Of Europe}} [[Category:Diplomacy]] [[Category:History of international relations]] [[Category:International organisations of Europe]] [[Category:Modern Europe]] [[Category:Post-Napoleonic congresses|*]] [[Category:19th-century diplomatic conferences|*]] [[Category:19th century in Europe]] [[Category:20th-century diplomatic conferences|*]] [[Category:20th century in Europe]] [[sl:Metternichov absolutizem]]
